bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: IN THE UNITED DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DETENTION OF SEVENTY-THREE HINDOO ALIENS.

It is an admitted fact that the aliens are held on warrants of deportation issues by authority of Section 20. It will be noted that Section 2 of the Act states that persons likely to become a public charge are subject to be excluded, but under the admission and authority of the Gonzales case, 192 U.S. 1, and the case of Suekichi, 199 Fed. 750, Section 2 is not to be applied to alien residents, but only alien immigrants.
These aliens are held under authority of the deportation warrants and these warrants give as the only ground for holding and deporting said aliens in that they
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY 430-3 PIONEER BUILDING SEATTLE

were likely to become public charges at the time of their entry, and those warrants have taken the place of the warrants of arrest (see heading at top of warrants) and the authorities hold that these warrants must be substantially correct and must be taken at their face value, and if errors have been made of a substantial nature, that the alien should be released on habeas corpus.

The courts have gone to the extent of holding that where the place where the aliens was to be deported was not stated in the warrant, but that there was a mere statement in said warrant that the alien should be deported to the country from whence he came, that that was insufficient, and the alien should be released on habeas corpus.

Attention is called to the affidavit of the interpreter attached hereto, who was present when about half the number of aliens in this case were examined by the immigration board at Manila, and passed, and this interperter furnishes letters from government officials, showing that he was the official interpreter. He testifies that these men were lawfully admitted at Manila and that they could not have received the certificates attached hereto, which it is an admitted fact in the record that all of the aliens possessed, unless they had first had a certificate signed by the immigration officials in Manila, which were presented to the aliens after a proper examination and an admission at a regular port of entry.

In all the cases that have come before the courts, it has been shown that the alien ran across the border at a place other than a regular port of entry or that the alien testified falsely to be admitted, or that in some surreptitious or clandestine manner the alien unlawfully entered. In this case there is not a word or a line of the testimony to show any unlawful entry, but there is a testimony to show that they went to Manila in a boat operated by one of the regular steamship lines, and the court will take judicial notice of the fact that these big ocean liners do not land their passengers at some hidden shore, but that they are met before landing at the port of Manila by the government officers and not a man is permitted to land until after he is inspected and examined by the immigration and custom officers. They testified they were examined regularly and passed, and described, apparently to the satisfaction of the government agents at Seattle, as they did not question the fact of the examination, that they had received an examination similar to the one received in Seattle, and had been passed as entitled to enter, from six months to three years ago at the port of Manila.

It will be noted by referring to Section 12 that the master or commanding officer of a steamer is required to make a report and to pay $4.00 head tax for every man on board who comes within the requirements, and about midway of that paragraph it is stated that no master of any vessel shall be granted clearance papers
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY 430-2 PIONEER BUILDING SEATTLE

for his vessel until he has deposited such list or lists with the collecter of customs, and further that the collecter of customs with whom such list has been deposited, in accordance with the provisions of this section, shall promptly notify the commissioner general of immigration. This is for the purpose of having alines who are about to land, examined properly by the proper board of immigration officers. After they were examined, as appears in the affidavit attached hereto, of the interperter, they are given the certificate marked "A", which it will be noted is signed by the immigration officals who conducted the examination, and that this certificate of identification, which shows proper admission and examination is then surrendered for the certificate marked "B", which it is an admitted fact, were held and surrendered to the government in every case, and special attention is called to the same interpreter's affidavit, in which he tells of having lost his original certificate which showed his having been admitted, and having to get a duplicate, in order to get the certificate which was held and surrendered to the government by each one of the aliens in this hearing. The government not only has failed to show an unlawful entry, but lawful entry, so far as it was in the power of the aliens to show, has been shown. It is preposterous to suppose that if the alien would send a cable to the immigration officer at Manila that he would look at his said records and tell said alien that his name was on the manifest showing him to

have lawfully arrived at Manila on a certain date, but the government, owning and controlling the records, could have gotten that information without any difficulty. The records are in the possession of the government, and it would tke this Honorable Court, or some other court, in order to secure this information from the government from their official records.

It seems conclusive that by reference to Section 36, page 17 of the immigration pamphlet, where it provides "that all aliens who shall enter the United States except at the seaports thereof, or at such place or places as the Secretary of Labor may from tiem to time designate, shall be adjudged to have entered the country unlawfully and shall be deported as provided by Sections 20 and 21 of this Act," especially inasmuch as the same section provides that the provision shall not effect the power of the commissioner general to regulate the entry and inspection of aliens along the borders of Canada and Mexico. After setting out in this section what the government deems to be an unlawful entry, and the aliens having all testifed and show evidence of an admission at Manila, and an examination, and as there is a total lack of evidence showing any kind of an unlawful entry, and further, inasmuch as the government did not demand a head tax from these aliens on entering Seattle, and as paragraph "E" of subdivision 3, page 22 of the pamphlet states that a head tax is not demanded from aliens who have been lawfully admitted to the United States who
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY 430-3 PIONEER BUILDING SEATTLE

later shall go entransit from one part of the United States to another, it seems doubtful to us if the court can find that the government has complied with section 20 of the law, and especially do these aliens not come within the provision of Section 2, as subdivision 4 of rule 14, page 33 of the pamphlet states that a failure to present a certificate shall be deemed presumptive evidence that an examination has not occured unless he shows that his presence in the country is lawful or that the limitation of the statute has expired, and certainly this provision is complied with when the alien has testified under oath that he was lawfully admitted and passed at Manila and resided there after such lawful admission for from six months to several years, in view of the faact that he was duly sworn and could be convicted of perjury for falsely swearing, and in view of the further fact that the courts have held that alien residents have the same protection and have the same status as citizens in these matters, and it will not be denied that the oath of a citizen or an alien resident, as the courts have unanimously decided these men to be, who has testifed definitely and positively of the lawful examination and admission, that that when connected with the fact of the furnishing of a certificate only granted after the surrender of a certificate signed by the immigration official, showing a proper examination, and when connected with the further fact that the interpreter who has testified herein, who is a resident of the city of Seattle, testifies that he was present when more than half
